image.altText: Baby Harlyn wearing headphones and with a filter applied to the photo of stars on her forehead

props.synopsis: A 22-month-old girl who died in a house fire is described as the "light of her parents' life" as her uncle pleads for public help.

title.children: Birthday party tragedy as girl dies in house fire

image.altText: A newborn turtle is held in someone's hand.

props.synopsis: A new online tool will help conservationist share and compare novel solutions to climate threats. Its founders hope it will inspire innovation and optimism amid grim global warming metrics.

title.children: New tool has given conservationists hope amid warming climate

image.altText: A police car with a mountain in the background.

props.synopsis: Police say a man is in a stable condition after he was shot in what they believe was a targeted incident linked to a "feud".

title.children: Shooting in Hobart's northern suburbs may be linked to a 'feud'

image.altText: Lucy Barnard with her dog, stands near the edge of a lake ringed by brown hills

props.synopsis: Lucy Barnard has received an Australian Geographic award part-way through her mission to become the first woman to walk from the southernmost tip of South America to the top of North America.

title.children: Meet the Australian Adventurer of the Year who's on a 30,000km walk

image.altText: August was attacked by a group of teenagers whilst catching the bus to work  2025-01-10 11:01:00

props.synopsis: August Vamplew says they had a "run-in" with a "girl gang" on public transport in Hobart, one of two alleged attacks on people with a disability reported so far this year. It's worried experts who say there's a lack of data to highlight the issue.

title.children: Calls to better understand violence against people with disabilities, after two public attacks in Hobart

image.altText: Lisa standing in grassland, with native trees behind her.

props.synopsis: In the middle of Tasmania sits a 5,000-hectare property once used for sheep grazing. But when the sheep farmers left, an unlikely buyer moved in.

title.children: Billionaire couple focus their fortune on conservation — and profit

image.altText: Exterior signage at Hobart Private Hospital.

props.synopsis: As Tasmanians struggle to keep up with the cost of living, out of pocket medical costs may soon be added to the list of financial woes if Bupa and Healthscope don't resolve soon.

title.children: Tasmanian patients facing out of pocket costs over private health dispute

image.altText: Donald Trump speaking into a microphone.

props.synopsis: Now officially the 47th president of the United States, Donald Trump has addressed the inauguration ceremony by declaring that the "golden age of the United States of America begins right now".

title.children: Watch Donald Trump take the oath of office vowing to put America first

image.altText: Chris Minns and Anthony Albanese speak to police on a street.

props.synopsis: A childcare centre has been set alight and graffitied with anti-Semitic words at Maroubra in Sydney's south-east overnight.

title.children: Minns vows to find 'bastards' responsible for latest anti-Semitic vandalism

image.altText: A cutout black and white picture of Donald Trump against a black background, surrounded by teal and red geometic shapes

props.synopsis: Another US TikTok outage isn’t off the cards. The only certainty is more upheaval, writes Ange Lavoipierre.

title.children: TikTok has taken an astronomical gamble on Trump

image.altText: A man dressed in a suit speaks into a microphone

props.synopsis: In the final hours of his presidency, Joe Biden has also pardoned retired general Mark Milley and members of the House committee that investigated the January 6 attack on the Capitol.

title.children: Biden issues pre-emptive pardons for his family and Dr Anthony Fauci

image.altText: A car with several people celebrating in it, including some holding flags.

props.synopsis: Palestinian activist Hadeel Hijazt has been held in an Israeli prison since June last year with no charges and no answers. She was freed in Sunday's ceasefire exchange, and is more determined than ever to speak out.

title.children: In the West Bank, Palestinians don't have to break laws to get arrested

image.altText: Alex de Minaur of Australia celebrates winning the second set.

props.synopsis: After telling fans on the weekend his "legs are back", Alex de Minaur proved it on his way to the Australian Open quarterfinals.

title.children: De Minaur is finally where he wants to be, and playing the tennis he needs to succeed

image.altText: Lyudmyla Kichenok refuses to shake hands with Kristina Mladenovic

props.synopsis: There is no love lost between doubles rivals, Sinner's power breaks the net, and the title of best rally in the Australian Open may have been decided. Here are the five quick hits from day nine of the Australian Open.

title.children: Quick hits: Hand shake snub, a broken net and the 'point of the tournament'

image.altText: A website advertising low prices on everyday brands.

props.synopsis: Wesfarmers says the deals website Catch is losing too much money and will be shut down. Meanwhile, the Australian dollar is up, as markets react to Donald Trump's inauguration. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Wesfarmers shutting down Catch amid extra competition

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: ASX losing steam as US futures slide on tariff threats
Optus says telco plans bought through Catch will continue
Unusued Catch vouchers to be refunded after April 30 shutdown

image.altText: A woman stands in front of a wall with flowers and candles marking a memorial

props.synopsis: The attacks by the two men both happened last November, prompting Chinese authorities to urge local governments to take action to prevent such incidents.

title.children: China executes men over deadly 'revenge on society' attacks

image.altText: An aerial view showing land with trees and the ocean.

props.synopsis: The South Australian government has approved a plan for a $330 million desalination plant to address projected water shortages by 2026, but not everyone is happy.

title.children: Water is set to run out in this region. Why do some reject a proposed fix?

props.synopsis: Around the clock coverage of news events as they break at home and abroad.

title.children: ABC News Channel live

image.altText: A close up of fidgeting hands. In the background, a psychologist watches on, taking notes.

props.synopsis: With roughly two-thirds of psychiatrists in NSW's public sector set to resign from today onwards, one worker who left last year stressed the importance of reform.

title.children: Psychiatrist who left NSW reflects on system 'in crisis'

image.altText: A hand holding a seatbelt.

props.synopsis: Every new Australian bus that has seatbelts will be required to have signs and audio announcements reminding passengers to wear them, as is seen in aircraft.

title.children: Hunter Valley wedding bus tragedy prompts seatbelt sign mandate

image.altText: Close up of Queensland Police Service-issued black gun in holster on navy pants

props.synopsis: An ABC analysis shows a number of people who were shot were allegedly armed with knives or guns during their interactions with police officers.

title.children: At least 13 people were shot by Queensland police last year

image.altText: A composite image of three young girls, smiling at the camera.

props.synopsis: Axel Rudakubana, 18, changed his pleas from not guilty to guilty on what was due to be the first day of his trial at Liverpool Crown Court.

title.children: Teen who stabbed girls at Taylor Swift dance event admits murder

image.altText: Man speaks in front of microphones.

props.synopsis: Troy Thompson has called for the Townsville council to be dissolved and labelled staff "unmotivated" in social media posts.

title.children: Suspended mayor under investigation blasts council on social media

image.altText: A trampoline lying on its edge in a garden on a suburban street.

props.synopsis: Some residents dealing with damage caused by rogue trampolines in the aftermath of severe weather in NSW say it is time for greater regulation.

title.children: No such thing as 'flying trampoline cover': How insurance companies consider claims

image.altText: A woman laying red berries in a rectangle.

props.synopsis: Australia is surrounded by coffee-growing countries like Papua New Guinea and Indonesia, but it imports most of its coffee from the other side of the world. With climate change and coffee bean prices skyrocketing, is it time to look closer to home?

title.children: Vietnam and Indonesia grow a lot of coffee — but not the type we prefer

image.altText: Two Australian cricketers, dressed in dark green, embrace. An England batter wearing red is in the background.

props.synopsis: Australia retains the Women's Ashes with a comprehensive 57-run victory over England in the first T20 at the SCG.

title.children: Australia retains Women's Ashes with dominant victory in first T20

image.altText: A pig-nosed turtle swims, flippers raised.

props.synopsis: A number of animals, plants and an entire ecosystem were added to Australia's extinction watch list in 2024. We look at the new species under threat.

title.children: Forty-one species added to Australia’s threatened list despite zero extinction target

image.altText: A flooded roadway in the Pilbara

props.synopsis: Severe Tropical Cyclone Sean is downgraded to a category three system off the coast of Western Australia after impacting residents in the state's north.

title.children: Tropical Cyclone Sean drops 20-year record rain, Geraldton hits 49.3C

image.altText: A white graffiti poster on a grey wall speaking of a woman who was raped and murdered

props.synopsis: An Indian court has sentenced the man convicted of raping and murdering a female doctor at a Kolkata hospital to life in prison.

title.children: Man who raped and murdered doctor in India jailed for life

image.altText: Luke Plapp holds up his hand and makes a horn gesture with his fingers

props.synopsis: Luke Plapp is primed to target overall honours at the Tour Down Under, with a former Tour de France winner offering some sage advice on how one of Australian cycling's biggest talents can deliver on his promise.

title.children: Australian cycling's 'Mr January' eyes off Tour Down Under glory

image.altText: A woman in front of a house with a red roof next to a home with roof all in a lighter colour.

props.synopsis: Maria Gourley has spent nearly two years in a legal dispute with her body corporate because she painted the roof of her Brisbane townhouse the wrong colour.

title.children: Resident vows to take 'disruptive' roof colour battle further

image.altText: Suzie Blade is wearing a pink jumper and foam rolling a set of pantry drawers.

props.synopsis: A facility in Melbourne's hospital precinct is boosting wellbeing for cancer patients and their loved ones, over cups of coffee and important conversations.

title.children: As she sat at Christmas lunch, Suzie was carrying a heavy secret

image.altText: Bike crash at the Tour Down Under

props.synopsis: Stuart O'Grady defended the safety of the Tour Down Under, and was backed up by one of the World Tour's most senior riders, after a spectator was injured in a high-speed crash.

title.children: 'That hurts me more than anybody': TDU director defends safety record after crash

image.altText: A photo from the set of Sing Sing, featuring its cast dressed up as pirates on stage, smiling for a photo with crew.

props.synopsis: Sing Sing is beautifully brought to life by the same inmates who lived the story, but this extraordinary tale is unfortunately hobbled by ordinary filmmaking.

title.children: Cliches aside, Sing Sing is a real-life prison drama worth investing in
